title-group.article-title: Melting and nonisothermal crystallization behavior of polypropylene/hemp fiber composites

article-meta.aff: 1College of Polymer Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
2Institute of Materials Science and Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
3State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering of China, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China

author-notes.corresp: Jie Yang, Institute of Materials Science and Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China Email: ppsf@scu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Melting and nonisothermal crystallization behaviors of polypropylene (PP) and PP/hemp fibers (HFs) composites was investigated by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) technique. The results show that the incorporation of HFs increases both the melting temperature (Tm) and crystallization temperature (Tc) of PP. Moreover, in comparison with PP/HF(70/30) composite, the addition of maleic anhydride-grafted PP (PP-MAH) results in a slight decrease in Tm but a significant increase in Tc of PP. The higher Tc of PP in the composites implies that HFs could act as nucleating agents for the crystallization of PP. Nonisothermal crystallization kinetics analysis was performed using Avrami and Mo models. The values of half-time (t1/2) and rate constant indicate that the crystallization rate increases with the increasing of cooling rate for all the specimens. However, the crystallization rate of PP/HF(70/30) composite is found to be lower than that of PP at a certain cooling rate. Additionally, the composite containing PP-MAH has the lowest crystallization rate. Lower overall crystallization rate of PP/HF composites compared to PP is probably due to sufficiently high density of nuclei, which hinders the transport of PP molecular chains to crystal surface during nonisothermal crystallization. The crystallization activation energies (ΔE) determined by Kissinger method are 207.4 KJ/m2, 218.5 KJ/m2, and 220.4 kJ/m2 for PP, PP/HF(70/30), and PP/HF/PP-MAH(70/30/5), respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Natural fibers, such as hemp, flax, jute, and kenaf have the advantages of low cost, low weight, reproducibility, ‘ecofriendly,’ and biodegradability compared to glass fiber and carbon fiber.1,2 Therefore, natural fiber-reinforced polymer composites have raised great attention and interest both in academia and in industry lately.3,4 Properties of fiber-reinforced composites depend on many factors like fiber/matrix adhesion, volume fraction of fiber, and processing conditions. It has been reported that the processing temperature of composites containing natural fibers should not exceed 200°C. In addition, for curaua fiber-reinforced polyolefin composites prepared by twin-screw extruder, Mano et al.5 has found that the increase in screw rotation speed caused a decrease in length, diameter, and aspect ratio of the fibers in composites due to the high shear forces acting in the molten polymer and transferred to the fibers. As a result, the reinforced effect of the fibers decreased. On account of the important criterion of interfacial adhesion in determining the mechanical and physical properties of natural fiber composites, currently, most of the attention is focused on the compatibility improvement between hydrophilic cellulose fiber and hydrophobic polymer.6,7 Accordingly, maleic anhydride (MAH) grafted polymers are most widely used to modify the interphase of the composites. Sunet al.8 has stated that the critical fiber length and the interfacial shear strength were 2.27 mm and 22.03 MPa, respectively, for sisal fiber-polypropylene (PP) composite with the addition of MAH-grafted PP (PP-MAH).

However, it is worth noting that polymer matrix morphology created during the processing cycle of heating (melting) and cooling (crystallization) is one of the significant factors determining the mechanical properties of semi-crystalline polymer composites.9 Also, it is well-known that during the crystallization of fiber-reinforced polymer, the reinforcing fibers could influence the crystallization process mainly exhibiting nucleation activity, crystal growth rate, and possibly initiating trans-crystallization.10–14 Choudhury15 has investigated the isothermal crystallization behavior of sisal fiber-reinforced high-density polyethylene (HDPE) composites. Because of strong nucleating ability of sisal fibers, it was found the sisal fiber/HDPE composites had higher crystallization rate than that of HDPE. Cui et al.16 have studied the nonisothermal crystallization behavior of wood fiber-reinforced HDPE composites. The incorporation of wood fibers resulted in slower crystallization rate of the composites. According to the authors, wood fibers limited the flow of polymer, restricted its rearrangement, and consequently caused delay in the crystallization process of HDPE. Sombatsompop et al.17 have analyzed the influence of wood sawdust particle contents on the nonisothermal crystallization behavior of wood sawdust/PP composites. They noted that the crystallization temperature (Tc) of the composites increased with increasing sawdust content, illustrating that sawdust could act as nucleating agents during crystallization of PP. However, they also found that the overall crystal growth rate of the composites was slower than that of PP. According to the authors, sawdust particles could act as nucleating agents during the nucleation stage to increase Tc of PP but act as interfering agents during the crystal growth stage to decrease the overall crystallization rate of PP.

Among natural fibers used in polymer composites, hemp is one of the most productive and useful plants known. Hemp fibers (HFs) have been used in various applications, such as textile,18 housing, and automotive. China is one of the top countries producing HFs. We19 have studied the mechanical properties and thermal stability of HF-reinforced PP composites. It was found that the Young's modulus of PP/HF composites was apparently higher than that of PP. Tensile and flexural strengths of 30 wt% HF-filled PP composites comprising 5 wt% PP-MAH increased by 20% and 92%, respectively, compared to PP. In addition, the incorporation of HFs shifted the start of the degradation process and the maximum decomposition temperatures of the components to higher temperatures.

In practice, thermoplastic composites are usually produced and processed under nonisothermal conditions (injection or extrusion molding, etc.). It is highly desired to investigate the crystallization behavior to optimize processing technology of natural fiber composites. However, very few detailed investigations have focused on the nonisothermal crystallization behavior of PP/HF composite. The aim of this article is to investigate the effect of HFs on melting and nonisothermal crystallization behavior of PP. Avrami analysis and Mo method are employed to study the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics of PP and PP/HF composites. The crystallization activation energy (ΔE) of the specimens is calculated with the method proposed by Kissinger.20 Besides, the influence of PP-MAH serving as compatilizer on the melting and nonisothermal crystallization behavior of PP/HF composite is also presented.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p:
PP (F401) with a melt flow rate (MFR) of 2.2 g/10 min (230°C/2.16 kg) was supplied by Lanzhou Petrochemical Co. Ltd, China. HFs was obtained from Quartermaster Equipment Institute of the People's Liberation Army General Logistics Department. PP-MAH (Polybond 3200) with a MFR of 123 g/10 min (230°C/2.16 kg) containing 1.2 wt% of MAH was supplied by Uniroyal Chemical, Middlebury. The PP/HF composites were prepared via melt-compounding. Before the preparation of the composites, all the components were dried in an oven at 80°C for at least 24 h. The composition used in this study is listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Composition used in this study
Samples PP (wt%) Hemp fiber (wt%) PP-MAH (wt%)
PP 100 0 0
PP30 70 30 0
PP530 70 30 5

The study of melting and nonisothermal crystallization behaviors of PP and PP/HF composites was carried out on DSC 204 F1 (NETZSCH Instruments) with samples of about 8 mg. The samples were first heated to 200°C quickly and maintained for 5 min to eliminate the thermal history. Then, each sample was cooled to 50°C at cooling rates 2.5, 5, 10, and 20°C/min, followed at a heating rate of 10°C/min, with the temperature maintained at 200°C for 2 min. All experiments were carried out under nitrogen atmosphere and the nitrogen flow rate was 50 mL/min. Prior to the test, all the samples were first dried in an oven at 80°C for at least 24 h.

sec.title: Melt-crystallization and subsequent melting behavior of PP and PP/HF composites
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the crystallization curves of the specimens at a given cooling rate of 10°C/min. According to Figure 1, an apparent exothermal peak at 111°C for PP is observed. In comparison with PP, the incorporation of HFs shifts the Tc to higher temperature (118°C for PP30). The increase in Tc suggests that HFs probably act as heterogeneous nucleating agents which causes the polymer to crystallize (nucleation stage) at higher temperature. Additionally, it can also be seen that PP530 had the highest Tc value (123°C). However, Grozdanov et al.21 observed that the Tc of unmodified kenaf/PP composite was higher than that of PP-MAH compatilized composite. The inconsistent result can be discussed as follows: the addition of PP-MAH could increase the Tc of PP.21,22 In PP-MAH compatilized composites prepared via direct melt-compounding, PP-MAH appears at not only fiber/matrix interface but also PP matrix.19,23 In PP/HF/PP-MAH(70/30/5) composite, HFs can provide nucleation sites for heterogeneous crystallization resulting in the increase of Tc, and PP-MAH present at polymer matrix can also increase the Tc of PP. Consequently, Tc of PP530 is higher than that of PP30. Figure 1.
Nonisothermal crystallization curves of PP and PP/HF composites at a cooling rate of 10°C/min.

Figure 2 shows the melting curves of PP and PP/HF composites after the process of crystallization at the cooling rate of 10°C/min. The crystallinity (X) of PP can be obtained using equation as follows24: (1)where ΔHm is the measured enthalpy of fusion, ΔH0 the enthalpy of fusion for 100% crystalline PP (ΔH0 = 209 J/g), and ω the mass fraction of PP in the composites. The calculated data of X are shown in Table 2. As expected, higher values of X are obtained for both PP30 and PP530 compared to that of PP. This can be attributed to the heterogeneous nucleation effect of HFs. Unexpectedly, the X of PP530 is sharply lower than that of PP30 but only a little higher than that of PP in spite of higher heterogeneous nucleation ability with the presence of HFs and the addition of PP-MAH. It is probably due to the sufficiently high density of nuclei impeding the transport of PP molecular chains to crystal surface during crystallization process. That is, although PP530 has the most number of nucleation sites, the rearrangement of molecular chains during crystallization is hindered due to the presence of HFs and possibly the addition of PP-MAH. Overall, it ends up having an X just a little higher than that of PP. From Figure 2, it can also be seen that the melting temperature (Tm) of both PP30 and PP530 is higher than that of PP. Moreover, the Tm of PP530 (166.8°C) is slightly lower than that of PP30 (168°C). It is known that polymer with higher X possesses higher Tm. From Table 2, it can be seen that PP30 has highest X while the X of PP is minimum at the same cooling rate. Therefore, the Tm of specimens has an order of Tm(PP30) > Tm(PP530) > Tm(PP), as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Melting curves of PP and PP/HF composites at a heating rate of 10°C/min.
Table 2.
Melting and nonisothermal crystallization kinetics parameters of PP and PP/HF composites from Avrami equation
Samples ϕ (K/min) n log Z t1/2 (min) Tp (°C) X (%) R
PP 2.5 2.94 −1.46 2.96 118.3 40 0.9995
5 2.88 −0.63 1.39 115.2 39 0.9963
10 2.80 0.23 0.68 111.5 38 0.9984
20 2.82 0.85 0.45 107.2 38 0.9995
PP30 2.5 2.42 −1.57 3.06 125.6 53 0.9994
5 2.57 −0.74 1.47 122.4 53 0.9998
10 2.41 0.09 0.77 118.2 51 0.9994
20 2.36 0.59 0.49 112.5 51 0.9989
PP530 2.5 2.46 −1.74 3.57 130.3 46 0.9989
5 2.53 −0.79 1.57 126.5 44 0.9979
10 2.51 −0.14 1.05 122.5 41 0.9989
20 2.54 0.57 0.54 118.1 40 0.9996
Note: R denotes correlation coefficient.

sec.title: Kinetics of nonisothermal crystallization
sec.p:
The relative crystallinity (Xt) as a function of crystallization temperature (T) can be formulated as follows11,25: (2) where T0 and T∞ are the initial and final crystallization temperatures, respectively, and dHc is the enthalpy at infinitesimal temperature dT. The developments of Xt with T of PP and PP/HF composites at various cooling rates are illustrated in Figure 3. It is observed that all the curves show a reversed sigmoidal shape, indicating a fast primary crystallization in the initial stage and a slow secondary crystallization during the later stage. The curvature of the upper parts of the plot is observed to be level off due to spherulite impingement which begins from the inflection point of the curves. It is worth noting that the spherulite impingement stage of PP30 (especially PP530) began at lower values Xt than that of PP. Moreover, the plots of Xt vs. T steadily shift to low temperature region with the increase of cooling rate. The reason is that at lower cooling rate, molecular chains possess more fluidity, more diffusability, and more time for perfect crystallization at high temperature.26 Therefore, samples show higher Tc, as shown in Table 2. Figure 3.
Relative crystallinity vs. temperature at various cooling rates of PP and PP/HF composites: (a) PP, (b) PP30, and (c) PP530.

During nonisothermal crystallization process, the relationship between crystallization time t and the corresponding temperature T can be represented as follows27: (3) where T0 and T are the onset crystallization temperature and the temperature at crystallization time t, respectively, and φ the cooling rate. According to Equation (3), the abscissa of temperature can be transformed into time scale. Thus, the plots of relative crystallinity, Xt, with t at different cooling rates are illustrated in Figure 4. It is clearly observed that the higher the cooling rate, the shorter the time of crystallization completion. Moreover, it seems that PP30 requires more t to approach the same Xt at various cooling rates compared to that of PP, and the t required for PP530 is longest, implying lower crystal growth rate of PP/HF composites. Through Figure 4, the half-time of crystallization, t1/2, when the Xt are equal to 50%, was calculated and the obtained values are listed in Table 2. Figure 4.
Relative crystallinity vs. time at various cooling rates of PP and PP/HF composites: (a) PP, (b) PP30, and (c) PP530.

From the results presented in Table 2, it can be seen t1/2 values of both PP and PP/HF composites decrease gradually with increasing cooling rate, indicating a progressively faster crystallization rate as the cooling rate increased. Comparing t1/2 values of PP30 and PP530 with those of PP at a certain cooling rate, it is clear that the t1/2 values of PP30 are higher, and PP530 values are the maximum at all cooling rates. The increased t1/2 values indicate that the overall crystallization rates of PP/HF composites are lower than that of PP. As is known, the overall crystallization rate is the result of nucleation and growth rate. HFs acts as heterogeneous nucleating agents which cause the polymer to crystallize at higher temperature. However, sufficiently high density of nuclei between HFs and the polymer matrix might play a role of physical cross-links which decelerate the rearrangement of PP molecular chains toward the growing surfaces of the polymer crystals.28 This behavior was also found in sawdust/PP composites by Sombatsompop et al.17 In addition, PP530 possesses the most number of nucleation sites with the presence of HFs and PP-MAH which would impede the molecular diffusion rate further. If this is the case, the X level of PP/HF composite is expected to decrease with the addition of PP-MAH. From Table 2, it can be seen clearly that the X of PP530 is apparently lower than that of PP30 at all cooling rates.

In addition to t1/2 values, other parameters (such as the kinetic rate constant) can also be used to characterize the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics. In this study, two different methods are used to discuss the nonisothermal crystallization process of PP and PP/HF composites.

sec.title: Analysis based on Avrami equation
sec.p:
Avrami equation has been widely used to analyze the isothermal crystallization behavior.29 With the assumption of a constant crystallization temperature, Avrami equation could still explain the initial stage of crystallization as follows30: (4) (5) where Xt is the relative crystallinity as a function of time t, n the Avrami exponent which relates to the type of nucleation as well as crystallization dimensional growth, and Z the crystallization rate constant representing crystallite nucleation and growth mechanisms. Plots of log(−ln(1 − Xt)) vs. log t at each cooling rate are shown in Figure 5. Each curve shows a very slight deviation at the beginning of crystallization, which is probably due to the existence of an induction period at the initial crystallization stage. After that, the curves exhibit good linear relationship with the Xt less than 80% for PP, and 70% for PP30 and PP530, indicating that the nucleation mechanism and crystal growth geometries are similar for the primary crystallization process at the different cooling rates. Finally, the linear lines tend to level off evidently. This deviation is usually considered to be due to the presence of secondary crystallization, which is caused by the slower crystallization and further perfection of crystals in the later stage.30,31 The Avrami exponent n and rate constant Z can be determined from the slope and intercept of the linear segment31 with the Xt of PP and PP/HF composites between 3% and 70%. The results are summarized in Table 2. Figure 5.
Plots of log(−ln(1 − Xt)) vs. log t at various cooling rates of PP and PP/HF composites: (a) PP, (b) PP30, and (c) PP530.

From the data presented in Table 2, it is evident that Avrami exponent n values of PP decrease with increasing cooling rates, suggesting that the less complicated nucleation mechanism and geometry could be predominant as the cooling rate increases because of the less available crystallization time. However, it is observed that the n values of both PP30 and PP530 do not change significantly with the increase of cooling rate. Moreover, at a certain cooling rate, the n values of both PP30 and PP530 are lower than that of PP, indicating HFs could act as heterogeneous nucleation agents. This is consistent with the Tc analysis results given above. In addition, the crystallization rate constant Z values of the specimens increase with increasing cooling rate. This is attributed to the fact that at higher cooling rate, melt crystallization occurs at lower temperature and thus has higher crystallization rate due to higher undercooling. Furthermore, at a certain cooling rate, it can be clearly determined that the Z values of PP30 are smaller, indicating slower overall crystallization rate of PP30 compared with that of PP. This is related to the inclusion of HFs could offer specific sites to crystallize, but plentiful nucleation sites could hinder the crystal growth under nonisothermal crystallization scans. Compared to PP30, there are more available sites to nucleate for PP530 with the presence of PP-MAH. Thus, the rearrangement of molecular chains toward crystal surface is limited further. Consequently, each crystal would grow to a smaller crystal grain size and cease to grow further. The effects are lower melting temperature and lower crystallinity of PP530 than that of PP30.

sec.title: Analysis based on Mo method
sec.p:
To compare different methods in evaluation of experimental results, the method developed by Mo and coworkers32 is used. This method is based on the Avrami and Ozawa equations. It can be formulated as follows: (6)where F(T) = (P(T)/Zt)1/m is the necessary value of cooling rate (φ) to reach a certain relative crystallinity at unit crystallization time and α = n/m the Avrami exponent divided by Ozawa exponent. The plots of ln φ vs. ln t at a certain values Xt are shown in Figure 6. The linearity of the plots shows that Mo method could satisfactorily describe the nonisothermal crystallization behavior of the samples.30,31 F(T) and α related to a given Xt can be obtained from the intercept and slope of each straight line, respectively. The calculated values are listed in Table 3. The values of F(T) increase with the increasing Xt. However, at the same Xt, the F(T) values of both PP30 and PP530 are higher than those of PP. Since F(T) reflects the difficulty of crystallization process, the higher values determined for the composites are in agreement with slower overall crystallization rate.32 Furthermore, the highest F(T) values of PP530 imply the slowest overall crystallization rate of the system. This is consistent with Avrami results given above. Figure 6.
Plots of ln φ vs. ln t of PP and PP/HF composites: (a) PP, (b) PP30, and (c) PP530.
Table 3.
Nonisothermal crystallization kinetics parameters of PP and PP/HF composites from Mo equation
Samples Xt (%) α F(T) R
PP 20 0.96 5.10 0.9975
40 1.06 7.07 0.9945
60 1.09 8.52 0.9974
80 1.14 10.49 0.9965
PP30 20 0.96 5.74 0.9797
40 0.99 7.01 0.9844
60 1.08 8.86 0.9894
80 1.18 11.94 0.9891
PP530 20 0.93 7.07 0.9990
40 0.97 8.66 0.9992
60 1.11 11.34 0.9941
80 1.11 13.89 0.9951
Note: R denotes correlation coefficient.

sec.title: Crystallization activation energy
sec.p: For nonisothermal crystallization, the crystallization activation energy (ΔE) can be estimated from the variation of crystallization peak temperature (Tc) with heating rates (ϕ) by the Kissinger approach (Equation (7)). It enables us to determine the difficulty for the transport of the macromolecular segments to the growing crystal surface.20 (7) where ΔE is the activation energy of the crystallization and R the universal gas constant.

Plots of ln(ϕ/Tp2) vs. 1/Tp for PP and PP/HF composites are shown in Figure 7. The slope of the curve gives ΔE/R. The calculated ΔE values for PP, PP30, and PP530 are 207.4, 218.5, and 220.4 KJ/m2, respectively. The slightly higher ΔE values of the composites demonstrate that the incorporation of HFs to PP makes the transportation of PP chain segments to the growing crystal surface difficult. Consequently, in spite of homogeneous nucleation effect of HFs, the overall crystallization rate is decelerated with the presence of HFs. In addition, the highest ΔE values of PP530 suggest the most difficult rearrangement of molecular chains to crystal surface during nonisothermal crystallization resulting in lowest crystallization rate. Figure 7.
Kissinger plots for evaluating nonisothermal crystallization activation energy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The nonisothermal crystallization kinetics and the melting behavior were investigated of PP/HF composites. The incorporation of HFs results in higher Tc of PP30 than that of PP suggesting that HFs could play a role of heterogeneous nucleating agents in PP crystallization. In addition, PP530 has the highest Tc values due to the presence of HFs and the addition of PP-MAH. Compared to PP, higher Tm and X values of PP30 are observed. However, the Tm and X of PP530 were lower than that of PP30, but still higher than PP.

Although, HFs could acts as heterogeneous nucleation agents, it could not accelerate the crystallization of PP. Besides the higher t1/2 value, lower Z and higher F(T) obtained from Avrami analysis and Mo method, respectively, indicate that PP30 has slower crystallization rate compared to PP at a certain cooling rate. This is due to the fact that plentiful nucleation sites in PP30 could hinder the rearrangement of PP molecular chains to crystal surface under nonisothermal crystallization scans. In addition, the overall crystallization rate of PP530 is the lowest. The number of available sites to nucleate in PP530 is the most with the presence of HFs and PP-MAH, and consequently, the inhibition of nuclei on the crystal growth is the strongest. The ΔE analysis (following the order of PP530 > PP30 > PP) reveals the action of HFs against PP macromolecular mobility in the composites.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the Quartermaster Equipment Institute of the People's Liberation Army General Logistics Department for hemp fiber provision.
